text: The glory of stratospheric dawn.  The engines of a silver Lockheed U-2F rasp upon the trace oxygen here at 72,500 f Scattered cloud formations hang over the blue brilliance sea far, far below.  In the haze, the looming edge of lan SUPER: FLIGHT G-3101. OCTOBER 14TH, 1962. OVER CUBA. The spy plane's CAMERA DOORS whine open.  The glassy eye the 36-inch camera focuses.  And then with a BANGBANGBANGBANG, its high-speed motor kicks in, shutter flying.

A simple CAMERA, snapping away furiously in the hands of giggling MARK O'DONNELL, 4.  He's straddling and in the f of his dad, KENNY O'DONNELL, 30's, tough, Boston-Irish, w a prodigious case of morning hair.  Kenny awakens, red-ey

Mark, get off your father! Kenny sits up to the morning bedlam of the O'Donnell hous KIDS screech, doors bang all over.  Kenny pushes Mark ove rolls out of bed, snatches up the corners of the blanket hoists Mark over his shoulder in a screaming, kicking bun
Kenny, with Mark in the bundle on his shoulder, meets his wife HELEN going the other way in the hall with LITTLE HE 1, in her arms.
Hi, hon. They kiss in passing.  Daughter KATHY, 12, races by in an pursuit of her twin, KEVIN, 12.
Don't forget, Mrs. Higgins wants to talk to you this afternoon about Kevin.  You need to do something about this.
Kids are supposed to get detention. Kenny dumps the bundle with Mark in a big pile of dirty laundry.

A pair of massive FILM CANISTERS unlock and drop from the belly of the U-2.  TECHNICIANS secure them in orange carr cases, lock them under key, fast and proficient.  They wh them out from under the spy plane. The Technicians run for an idling Jeep.  They sling the c into the rear of the vehicle which in turn accelerates aw hard, curving across the runway for another waiting plane

A kitchen out of the late 1950's.  Kenny drinks coffee, t a tie, rifles through a briefcase at the kitchen table. horde of kids, ages 2-14, breakfast on an array of period food.  Kenny grills the kids while he goes over papers.
Secretary of Defense...
Dean Rusk!
Wrong, and you get to wax my car. KENNY JR. smirk at Kevin.
Rusk is State, moron.  Robert McNamara.
Got time for pancakes?
Nope.  Attorney General? A PHONE RINGS as the kids cry out en masse.
(chorus)
Too easy!  Bobby, Bobby Kennedy! Kenny glances up at the wall.  There are two phones, side side.  One RED, one BLACK.  It's the black one ringing.  Helen answers.  Kenny goes back to his papers.
All right, wise guys, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America...

A U.S. Navy truck lurches to a stop in front of the run-d brick-faced seven-story Steuart Building on 5th and K.  R doors BANG open, and out hop two MARINE GUARDS, side arms drawn, film canisters in a carrying case between them.
As the Marines approach the building, front doors SLAM op

A bespectacled OPERATIONS MANAGER hands a clipboard to on the big Marine Guards who in turn hands him a set of keys The Manager unlocks the film cases.  PHOTO INTERPRETERS s in, whisk away the contents: SPOOLS OF FILM.
A black Lincoln pulls away from the modest white house on tidy Washington D.C. residential street.

The car threads its way through the Washington traffic, p the big administrative buildings, down tree-lined avenues takes a turn into a gate.  As the car stops at the gate, CAMERA flies past, revealing it's the gate to the WHITE HOUSE.
CLOSE ON the five-thousand rolls of film spewing through processing equipment, its streaking passage leading us straight through the development machinery to:

Photo Interpreters power up light tables, stereoscopic viewers, zip across the floor in wheeled chairs. Flying switches, flickering lights, humming motors.  It's eerie dance of technological black magic. Another pair of Interpreters loom out of the darkness, si by side, ghostly looking, their glasses reflecting the gl of the light table, like magicians staring into a crystal ball.

Aerial shots, flashing by.  Cuban countryside from 72,500 feet.  A MAGNIFYING GLASS swings down on its arm in front us, magnifying the carpet of trees... and a row of six ca covered OBJECTS among them.
Kenny, in business suit and tie, trots up the steps, and MARINE GUARD snaps the door open for him.

Kenny, briefcase in hand, weaves his way through the empt ornate hallways of the West Wing.  Past magnificent doorw early American furniture, paintings.  He finally reaches doorway, goes through into:

A long, narrow affair, window at the back looking out int the Rose Garden.  Kenny dumps his briefcase on the desk, shucks off his coat, removes a folder from his briefcase, turns and heads back out...
And into the warren of offices and halls that is the work White House.  He takes a right, passes the doors to the O Office right next to his office, goes down a long, straig hall, into...
The formal main building, the executive mansion.  He pass the busts of Presidents past, turns left into an elevator The doors close.

The doors open.  Kenny strides out onto a DIFFERENT FLOOR the third.  He heads down the long, posh hall of the fami quarters.  Fine furnishings, art.  The living White House He approaches the double doors at the end of the hall gua by a cluster of SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  An agent opens on the doors.
Morning, Floyd.
Good morning, Mr. O'Donnell.
Kenny enters the elegant bedroom.  The figure alone at a table by the window, drinks coffee, breakfast still sprea out before him, Washington Post obscuring his face.

Top o' the morning, Mr. President. The figure lowers the paper. It is PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY.  He's wearing boxers and tank top.  Unshaven.  Bed-head. Kenny O'Donnell, former ward-pol and long-time Kennedy ma is his Chief of Staff...
Morning, Kenny.  You see this goddamn Capehart stuff? The President rattles the paper.  Kenny collapses in the chair opposite the President, sprawls, comfortable.
Bayh's going to lose, but it's good groundwork for us for '64. Kenny steals a piece of buttered toast off the President' plate.  The President spares him a glance.
I was eating that.
No you weren't.
(scanning the paper)
I was, you bastard. Kenny takes a defiant bite.
So what've we got today?
Today, for your information, is Pulaski Day.  We're going to Buffalo...

A luxury hotel crowded with LOCAL POLS: the Democratic machine of Buffalo.  Beyond the open floor-to-ceiling windows, a CROWD.  The Pulaski Day Parade, a glimpse of ' Americana.  High School bands blare Sousa.  The scene is deafening, boisterous.  Pols trail Kenny as he crosses th room: fast, tough, on-the-go.
We're putting up Potowski next time.  Will you guys come out for him?
Who else you got?
There's Richardson.  Good kid.
Got the touch?
Yeah.  Still moldable, too.

Everyone likes a good kid... And like that, a congressional candidate is made...  Kenn accelerates, leaving the Pols behind.  Suddenly, outside windows, the crowd swells forward with a collective ROAR.
Kenny heads down the steps with New York Times Washington Bureau Chief, SCOTTY RESTON. Anonymous, they weave their through the crowd for a police car on a side street.
How's my favorite President?
Busy.  But you've got his heart.
I want an hour with him.
I said his heart, not his attention.
Three weeks before midterm elections?  You need me.
Well.  There is a new civil rights initiative he wants to talk about.

I'm doing a piece on Skybolt.  I hear Macmillan's meeting with him in Nassau. Kenny just sighs as they make their way up to the police A Secret Service Agent opens the door for him, another is behind the wheel.

We're giving the Brits Polaris instead.  But a story'll just aggravate things. Scotty stares at Kenny, determined.  Kenny looks away.  A his eye catches a tall, willowy BEAUTIFUL WOMAN.  She is talking, excited, embarrassed, to two more SECRET SERVICE AGENTS.  What they're saying is lost in the noise. Scotty follows Kenny's gaze.  Then the two men share a lo a silent understanding.  Kenny glances at the Secret Serv guy holding the car door, tilts his head at the woman.
Not today.  He's got tight schedule. The Agent nods, heads for the other Agents and the Beauti Woman.  Scotty acts like nothing has happened.
Pretending there isn't a problem won't fix it.  He can clear the air on Anglo American relations.
Forget it, Scotty.

Let him talk to me, he makes Macmillan look good, I print it, the British public likes it, Macmillan owes you. The formula's exactly what Kenny wants to hear.  He prete to consider, pretends to cave as he gets in the car.
All right, you're in.  Half hour. Reston's won.  But so has Kenny, and he's made Scotty fee tough in the bargain.  People like Kenny.

In the back seat, Kenny stares out the window at the para goers.  The Secret Service Agents leave the Woman.  Disappointed, the Woman turns and vanishes into the crowd It's an eerie moment.  Something troubles Kenny, and he glances up at the sky.  A premonition.  But it's a clear, clear blue.  A day like this, all is right with the world

Six Interpreters huddle around IMAGES on a light table. of them shoulders his way into the group and THUMPS a bla BINDER on the table.  There are grim nods of agreement. The book is open to a PICTURE of an SS-4 BALLISTIC MISSIL A photo from Moscow Mayday parade.  An icon of the nuclea age escorted like some devil-god to a holocaust...
The White House casts long shadows this gorgeous October morning.  Blue sky; the first flash of color in the trees SUPER: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 16TH, 1962.  DAY 1.

Briefcase and coat in hand, Kenny enters his office - and finds THREE MEN.  Standing there.  Thin-haired, bespectac academic-looking MCGEORGE BUNDY, 43, the National Securit Advisor.  The two men in the background: PHOTO INTERPRETE Kenny hangs up his coat, sees the Interpreters' large bla display cases.  And suddenly the world is slightly off kilter.
Hey, Mac.  You're up bright and early.
No, Ken.  I need to see him now...

Kenny emerges from the elevator with Bundy.  They head do the long, posh 3rd floor hall, the Presidential Detail guarding the doors at the end.  But the familiar route fe strange, and lasting an eternity.  Kenny eyes the package under Bundy's arm, its TOP SECRET stamp visible.
Morning, Floyd.
Good morning, Mr. O'Donnell.  Mr. Bundy. The Agent opens the door.  Bundy pauses, Kenny with him.
What's it about?
Cuba. Bundy is tense.  But Kenny relaxes.
Just Cuba?  Okay, I got work to do, see you guys downstairs.
Kenny's office is a raging beehive of activity.  Kenny wo the phone as ASSISTANTS come and go with files.
(to phone, scary calm)
Listen to me, you worthless piece of disloyal shit.  You will pull Daly's man on the circuit.  You owe your goddamn job to this administration. (beat, listening)

There is a word you need to learn.  It is the only word in politics.  Loyalty.  LOYALTY you motherfucking piece of shit! As Kenny THROWS the phone down at the receiver, and the PRIVATE DOOR to the Oval Office suddenly opens.  Kenny glances up.  President Kennedy stands there in the doorwa Kenny thinks he's reacting to the tirade.
What're you looking at?  This isn't the blessed order of St. Mary the Meek. Kenny stops.
Excuse us. The Assistants leave, shutting the door after them.  Kenn rises.
I think you should come in here. Kenny starts for the door.
Still think Cuba isn't important?
Not as far as the election goes. The President lets Kenny by into...

WE ENTER from a different angle than we usually enter in movies: through the side door.  The President's ornate de sits on the right, windows looking out on the Rose Garden behind it.  Kenny's gaze swivels to: THE OTHER END OF THE ROOM where the Interpreters, their crewcut chief, ARTHUR LUNDAHL, 50's, and Bundy stare at h They're surrounded by PRESENTATION BOARDS propped up arou the fireplace.  The President's rocking chair and sofas.

You used to look down a bomb sight for a living, Ken.  What do you see? In eerie silence, as all eyes follow him, Kenny makes his among the presentation boards with the U-2 imagery, stops front of the picture of the six canvas-covered objects. unleashes a wave of memories.
We hit a Nazi buzz bomb field in '45.  (beat, incredulous)
It looks like a rocket base... He puts his hand out to touch the image, then turns and l to the President, knowing what they must be.
On Sunday morning, one of our U-2s took these pictures.  The Soviets are putting medium range ballistic missiles into Cuba. Shock.  Silence.  Kenny glances to the other men.
They appear to be the SS-4: range of a thousand miles, three-megaton nuclear warhead.
Jesus Christ in Heaven...
A bank of WHITE HOUSE OPERATORS work the switchboard, fin flying, voices overlapping in a babble of:
Please hold for the White House...Mr. O'Donnell for Secretary McNamara... White House Operator... please hold...
Kenny carries the phone with him as he paces hard from hi desk to his window.

The principals are assembling in an hour.  See you then. Kenny hangs up.  The President enters.  A beat.  And in t beat, there's a void.  The two men are off their emotiona stride, trying to grope their way out of shock.
Where's Bobby? Kenny nods, acknowledging the feeling
Should be here any minute.
Good. And we glimpse the chemistry of these guys by Bobby's absence.  It's like they're missing their third wheel.
Good.
Where the hell are you? The President and Kenny hear him out in the hall.  And th tension goes out of them instantly.

In here! They turn to the door as BOBBY KENNEDY, 37, the President younger brother/Attorney General, enters.  Bobby shuts th door behind him, falls into Kenny's chair, and clearly grappling with his own disbelief, is hushed.
Jesus Christ, guys.  What the hell's Khruschev thinking?
Did you have any indication of this from Georgi?  Any possible warning or sense of motivation?
(shaking his head)
Complete snowjob.  And then we went out and told the country they weren't putting missiles into Cuba. (beat)
By the way, you realize we just lost the midterms.
Who gives a shit about the midterms now?  The Soviets are putting nuclear weapons ninety miles away from us.
You mean there's something more important than votes?  Didn't think I'd live to see the day, Ken. The President paces away, grim.
Jesus.  I feel like we've caught the Jap carriers steaming for Pearl Harbor.

The President strides down the plush hallway, Bobby and K flanking him.  Unconsciously, all three men assume the sa gait: confident, powerful, no longer disoriented. And before our eyes, the three men's game faces appear, a they become the hard-ass leaders of the United States.  Secret Service Agents throw open the massive double doors the Cabinet Room.
And they enter.  The group of men at the long, ornate Roosevelt-era table, rise as one.
Good morning, Mr. President.

Good morning, gentlemen. And the doors close on the eighteen men of EXCOM: The Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  Th are the legendary "Best and Brightest." The President makes his way down the line: shakes hands w Secretary of State DEAN RUSK, 53, distinguished, with a s Georgian accent, a distant reserve.
Dean, good morning.
Mr. President. The President leans past him, grasps the hand of the Secretary of Defense ROBERT MCNAMARA, 46, a gifted manage genius... the price of which is a cold, hard personality.
Bob.  Bet you had a late night.
Sleep is for the weak, Mr. President. OFF TO THE SIDE, Kenny greets Vice President LYNDON JOHNS 54, and ADLAI STEVENSON, 62, Representative to the U.N., intellectual, well-spoken.
Lyndon.  Adlai. The silver-haired war hero and politically savvy Chairman The Joint Chiefs of Staff, GENERAL MAXWELL TAYLOR, 50s, shakes the President's hand.
Max.

McCone's been notified and is coming back from the West coast.  Carter's here, though. He gestures to GENERAL MARSHALL CARTER, Deputy Chief of Operations for the CIA.  Carter nods to the President. THE CAMERA PANS OVER THE OTHERS. DOUGLAS DILLON, ex-banker, Secretary of the Treasury. ROSWELL GILPATRIC, studious Deputy Secretary of Defense. PAUL NITZE, 55, the detail-driven facts man, Assistant Secretary of Defense. GEORGE BALL, 50s, Undersecretary of State.  Eloquent, a m of conscience. U. ALEXIS JOHNSON, Deputy Under Secretary of State. EDWARD MARTIN, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America. LLEWELLYN THOMPSON, laid back, rumpled Soviet Affairs Advisor. DON WILSON, Deputy Director of the USIA. The President sits down at the center of the table, Rusk McNamara to either side, and the others resume their seat Bobby takes one of the over-stuffed chairs at the table. Kenny finds one along the wall behind the President, unde the windows to the Rose Garden to TED SORENSEN, 30s, the President's legal counsel and speech writer.  They greet other coolly.
Ted.
Kenny. The room falls silent.  The President looks across the ta to GENERAL CARTER.
Okay.  Let's have it.

Arthur Lundahl heads our photographic interpretation division at CIA.  I'll let him and his boys take you through what we've got.  Arthur? Lundahl, standing at the end of the room with briefing boards, steps forward with a pointer.
Gentlemen, as most of you now know a U-2 over Cuba on Sunday morning took a series of disturbing photographs.
The sweltering Cuban countryside.  Shouting SOVIET ROCKET TROOPS, stripped to the waist, glistening with sweat, mac a clearing under scattered, limp palm trees.

Our analysis at NPIC indicates the Soviet Union has followed its conventional weapons build-up in Cuba with the introduction of surface-to surface medium-range ballistic missiles, or MRBMs.  Our official estimate at this time is that this missile system is the SS-4 Sandal.  We do not believe these missiles are as yet operational. A bulldozer TEARS through the undergrowth.  FILLING THE SCREEN.  A 70-foot long MISSILE TRANSPORTER creeps along the bulldozer's wake like a vast hearse with its shrouded cargo.
Lundahl raps his second board: a map of the United States Cuba visible in the lower corner.  An ARC is drawn clearl across the U.S., encompassing the entire Southeast.

IRONBARK reports the SS-4 can deliver a 3-megaton nuclear weapon 1000 miles.  So far we have identified 32 missiles served by around 3400 men, undoubtedly all Soviet personnel.  Our cities and military installations in the Southeast, as far north as Washington, are in range of these weapons, and in the event of a launch, would only have five minutes of warning.
Five minutes, gentlemen.  Five minutes.

In those five minutes they could kill 80 million Americans and destroy a significant number of our bomber bases, degrading our retaliatory options.  The Joint Chiefs' consensus is that this is a massively destabilizing move, upsetting the nuclear balance. The President stares at Lundahl, and beating out each wor
Arthur.  Are. You. Sure? Lundahl looks around the room.  Everyone is hanging.
Yes, Mr. President.  These are nuclear missiles. The men come to grips with their own fears, own anger.
How long until they're operational?
General Taylor can answer that question better than I can. General Taylor drops a memo on the table WHICH BECOMES:
SCHEMATICS slapped down on a camp table.  A group of Sovi site ENGINEERS point and gesture as they study their grou from a shaded hillock.  CLEARING CREWS and SURVEYORS work sweat in the distance.
GMAIC estimates ten to fourteen days.  However, a crash program to ready the missiles could cut that time.
Taylor sees the grim looks all around.
I have to stress that there may be more missiles that we don't know about.  We need more U-2 coverage. Kenny lets out his breath.  He catches Bobby's eye.  This unbelievable.
Is there any indication - anything at all - that suggests they intend to use these missiles in some sort of first strike?
Not at present, sir.  But I think the prudent answer is we don't know.
Do we have any sort of intelligence from CIA on what Khruschev is thinking?
No, Mr. President.  We don't.  We just don't know what's happening inside the Kremlin at that level.

They lied to us.  Two weeks ago Dobrynin told me to my face Khurschev had no intention of putting missiles into Cuba.  They said themselves, this is our backyard. There's angry agreement.  The President cuts it off.

Gentlemen, I want first reactions.  Assuming for a moment Khruschev has not gone off the deep end and intends to start World War Three, what are we looking at? Rusk glances to his team at the end of the table.  Ball, Johnson, Martin, Thompson and Stevenson.

Mr. President, I believe my team is in agreement.  If we permit the introduction of nuclear missiles to a Soviet satellite nation in our hemisphere, the diplomatic consequences will be too terrible to contemplate.  The Russians are trying to show the world they can do whatever they want, wherever they want, and we're powerless to stop them.  If they succeed...
It will be Munich all over again.

Appeasement only makes the aggressor more aggressive.  Confidence in our security commitments around the world will falter, allies will become unsure in the face of Soviet pressure, and the Soviets will be emboldened to push us even harder.  We must remove the missiles one way or another.  It seems to me the options are either to build up the crisis 'til they give in, or we hit them.  An air strike. There's silence at the table.  Some nods.  Understanding.
Bob?

We've worked up several military scenarios.  Before I ask General Taylor to lead us through the various options, I'd like for us to adopt a rule.  If we are going to strike, we must agree now that we will do it before the missiles become operational.  Because once they are, I don't think we can guarantee getting them all before at least some are launched. And there it is.  The clock is running.

Sir.  We need to consider... if we decide to act, there's a good chance we'll end up in a general war. The room falls silent.  The President leans back in his chair, studying the circle of men around the table, weigh them. Kenny and the others watch him in silence.  A long, drama pause.  A course that will change history is about to be chosen.  The President leans forward, folds his hands on table.  Fated.  Grave.
It's clear we cannot permit Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba.  We must get those missiles out.
Kenny and Bobby follow the President down a path through Rose Garden.  The shock of the morning has worn off.  The President stops, looks at them.
I don't think it's going to matter what Khruschev's intentions are.  I tell you, right now... I don't see any way around hitting them. A long moment of silence as they move along again.

If we hit 'em, kill a lot of Russians, they'll move against Berlin.  They attack Berlin, that's NATO... and we're at war. The guys stop again.  The autumn day is bright, warm, ali The air, the distant city sounds derail the relentless tr of logic for a beat.  And in their faces we see that all three men, for the first time, feel the enormity of war, shadow over everything.  It's only a couple of steps away Steps that they're seriously contemplating.
Damned if we do, but if we don't, we're in a war for sure somewhere else in six months. Pained, the President turns away.
No choice.  This is going to cost lives any way we go.  Do nothing, and it could be 80 million  of ours.  We have to get rid of those missiles.
There've got to be alternatives to just going out and bombing them.
He's right, Jack.  Taylor is saying we may have some time.  We've got to use it.
So if there are alternatives that make sense - and I'm not saying there are - we need 'em.  Need 'em fast.

What about the allies?  Congress?  I think we may need to start letting key people know.  And they're all scattered across the country for the campaign.  We're going to need to get the U.N. staff in and warmed up.  Jesus... I don't even know if we've got secure communications with half our embassies since that the Soviets got that cryptographer of ours.
We can't worry about everything right now.  We've got to figure out what we're going to do before we worry about how we do it.
The other thing is...
... I know.  CIA and the military fucked us on the Bay of Pigs.

They're going to be pressing for a military solution soon.  We can't afford to let them ram their agenda down our throats.  We need to come with options other than air strikes so we have some sort of choice here.
We got a bunch of smart guys.  We lock 'em up together in there, kick 'em in the ass til they come up with options. Kenny and the President look at him.  Bobby nods.
I'll do it.
(to the President)
It's too politicized with you in there, anyway.  They need to be able to stick their necks out.

It'll be the principals, a couple of the key guys from each department: the Executive Committee of the National Security Council.  We'll call it EXCOM. Kenny snorts a laugh.  Bobby shoots him a cross look.
EXCOM.  Has a ring to it.  Like F-Troop. The President stops.  Bobby and Kenny stop, too.
Okay.  Kenny and I only show for the meetings you call us into.  Impress us.  And do it fast. (to Kenny)
You're in charge of keeping this quiet.  If word gets out before we know what we're going to do, there'll be panic.  And it'll ruin any chance of surprise if we decide to hit them.

Then we need to do a few things right away.  No Pierre.  He knows, the press knows.  You're going to have to keep up your schedule - your movements are followed too closely.  And we need to get these guys out of the White House.  George Ball's got a conference room at State. (to Bobby)
Reconvene over there this afternoon, come back here tonight. Bobby nods.
I think we should bring in Dean Acheson.  He was fighting Soviets while we were still working the wards in Boston. The President nods his approval.  Looks at Kenny.
Find him, Kenny.  We're going to need all the help we can get.
Kenny moves hard and fast through the twisting warren of hallways and tiny offices which is the West Wing.  Sudden Scotty Reston pops out of a doorway behind Kenny.

Hey, Kenny!  Who died? Kenny glances over his shoulder at Scotty who points to a window.  A beat, then Kenny returns to look out the windo Outside, the West Wing Drive is FILLED WITH LIMOUSINES. A flash of dismay, but Kenny covers fast.

Way it's going, the Democratic Party.  DNC strategy session.  If you can call it that. Scotty chuckles.  Kenny moves off, leading him away.  Ken assistant runs up behind him, holding out a slip of paper
Sir? Kenny tries to look him away.
It's Tuesday.  You said to call.  When do I get my 45 minutes?
Tell you what.  We're in Connecticut tomorrow for Ribicoff.  I'll get you up front with him during the flight.
Deal.
Sir. Kenny turns, harsh
What is it? The Assistant eyes Scotty, holds his tongue.  Kenny takes slips.
The number you asked for.
I ask for a lot of 'em.  Whose is it?
Dean Acheson's, sir. That shuts Kenny up.  Reston eyes the slip, then looks to Kenny's face.  And he knows something isn't right here.
Gotta go, Scotty.  See you tomorrow.

A car jolts to a stop.  The CAMERA PANS up over the saggi suspension, the government plates, the hood ornament revealing half of EXCOM inside.  Kenny stands nearby wait for them. The doors open, and out they pile like a bunch of clowns: Bobby, McNamara, Rusk, Ball, Martin, Dioptric, Sorensen, Stevenson, and Nitze.  They're sitting in each others' la banging their heads on the roof, joking, but tense.
Screw secrecy.  You try having that fat ass sit on your lap all the way from Foggy Bottom.
You were excited.  I say no more. The gang falls in behind Kenny, trails him out of the gar

A steel door unlocks, swings open, and Kenny marches at t head of the wedge of men into a long tunnel.  It's the infamous old passage from the Treasury to the White House Kenny and Bobby get a little ahead of the others.
Everybody agrees the diplomatic route is out.  It's too slow, and they'll have the missiles finished. Kenny looks at him.  Then there's only one alternative. CAMERA wipes through the ceiling to:
GROUND LEVEL.  Where the brilliantly-lit flag flutters ov the spotlit White House: their destination.

GENERAL WALTER 'CAM' SWEENEY, head of Tactical Air Comman stands at the head of the table with a presentation board The men of EXCOM gather around Sweeney in their rumpled shirts, nursing coffee and cigarettes.
We have 850 planes assembling at Homestead, Eglin, Opa Locka, MacDill, Patrick, Pensacola and Key West.

An F-100 Super Sabre stands under lights on a taxiway.  T CAMERA DESCENDS FROM ITS OVERHEAD SHOT, discovering the aircraft's sleek cockpit, menacing tiger-jaw paint job, t four 20mm cannons on its nose.
Due to the tropical foliage, the OPLAN calls for high-explosive and napalm loadouts for our ground attack sorties.
The FLIGHT LINE where a full strike wing stands beyond th plane, pylons laden with weapons, GROUND CREW servicing t

Other EXCOM members draw near the board, its order of bat strike maps.  They're grim, but fascinated.  Empowering.  Intoxicating.  Sexy.  Kenny sees it in the faces, even th President's.  Adlai does too, is upset.
I still think there are diplomatic approaches we haven't considered yet. Kenny looks at Adlai.  The others around the room, embarrassed, don't respond.  The group has moved on and Stevenson hasn't.
We have high confidence in the expanded air strike option. (beat)

The problem, Mr. President, is that it's a short-term solution.  Khruschev can send more missiles next month.  The Chiefs and I believe we should follow up the air strikes with the full version of OPLAN 316.
An invasion...

Yes, sir.  We can be sure we get all the missiles, and we remove Castro so this can never happen again. Kenny looks around the room at the men, the murmurs of general agreement, senses the consensus building and is agitated.
Is this the Chiefs' recommendation?

Yes, sir.  Our best option is to commence the strikes before the missiles are operational.  The invasion happens eight days later. The President leans back in his chair, turns to the man a the far end of the table: DEAN ACHESON, 60s, former Secre of State.  He sits silent, like some revered oracle, the architect of the American Cold War strategy of containmen
Dean.  What do you think? Acheson arches an eyebrow, and when he speaks, his voice resonates throughout the room, powerful, smooth, hypnotic

Mr. President, you have rightly dismissed the diplomatic option.  The Soviet will only tie you down in negotiation, and leave us short of our goal, the removal of the missiles.  Negotiating will do nothing more than give them time to make the missiles operational, complicating the necessary military task we have at hand. Now let's tell the people...

Kenny stands there in the doorway, arms folded.  As we PU AWAY FROM HIM, we REVEAL the three NETWORK T.V. CAMERAS staring straight at us.  Their red lights go on as one, a we swing around REVERSING TO: The President at his desk: telegenic, powerful.
Good evening, my fellow citizens.  This Government, as promised, has maintained the closest surveillance of the Soviet military build-up on the island of Cuba...
The first B-52 trundles to a stop at the end of the runwa It begins to throttle-up, the ROAR of its engine mounting

...unmistakable evidence has now established the fact that a series of missile sites is in preparation on that imprisoned island.  The purpose of these bases can be none other than to proved a nuclear strike capability against the Western Hemisphere... -- AND DROWNING OUT the President's speech as the plane lurches forward, down the runway into the night.
The Titan solo door GRINDS OPEN.  And the missile inside begins to rise into the white bath of the crossed spotlig

Therefore, in the defense of our own security and under the authority of the Constitution, I have directed that the following initial steps be taken.  First, to halt this offensive build-up, a strict quarantine --
The President's words conjure the ESSEX battlegroup, its destroyers plunging through heavy seas, lit up in the nig

-- on all offensive military equipment under shipment to Cuba is being initiated.  All ships of any kind bound for Cuba, if found to contain cargoes of offensive weapons, will be turned back.  Second: I have directed the continued and increased close surveillance of Cuba and its military build-up.  Should these offensive military preparations continue, further action will be justified --
A flight of F-4 PHANTOMS drops INTO FRAME, lights flashin
-- I have directed the Armed Forces to prepare for any eventualities.
A beat.  And the President looks up from his notes.

And third: it shall be the policy of this nation to regard any nuclear missile launched from Cuba against any nation in the Western Hemisphere as an attack by the Soviet Union on the United States, requiring a full retaliatory response upon the Soviet Union... The chilling words hang there in the air.  BLEEDING IN: t rising and falling WOOP WOOP WOOP WOOP which becomes --

-- the voice of the Essex battlegroup: sparkling, alive, constellation of lights scattered across the sea.  One by the escort ships answer the carrier's SIREN with their ow wailing cries, an alien chorus among the ships, disappear and reappearing in the swells.  The communication crescen to its fever pitch -- -- and then the battlegroup goes to blackout.  Like a dyi universe, the answering sirens cut off, the life-lights w out, and an appalling darkness falls across the sea...
BLACKNESS, LIKE BEFORE A CURTAIN RISES.  And then a flickering: a FLUORESCENT LIGHT COMES ON.
Kenny, stripped to the waist, Sorensen and Bundy shave in nearby sinks.  Bobby barges in.
We're getting the Soviet response.
Specks of shaving cream still on his face, Kenny paces, r the inky carbon as Bobby, Bundy and Sorensen read copies.
This is all rhetoric. (realizing)
They don't know how to respond yet. Kenny looks up.  The President enters from the Oval Offic
So now you're Khurschev.  What do you do?
Kenny, arms folded, stands behind the President, the rest EXCOM is looking at him.
-- run the blockade.  They'll run the blockade. ADMIRAL GEORGE ANDERSON, 50s, dapper, the Chief of Naval Operations, nods from the far end of the table.

Which is exactly what they appear to be preparing to do, Mr. President.  We're tracking 26 ships inbound to Cuba.  There's no sign they're changing course.  The closest ships, the Gagarin and the Kimovsk, will make the quarantine line by this time tomorrow.

We're concerned about the possibility of an incident with an innocent cargo carrier.  If it turns ugly, the Russians could use an ugly incident and bad world opinion as leverage to force us to remove the quarantine.
Or they could use it as an excuse to escalate.
Admiral Anderson, if the ships do not stop, what exactly are our rules of engagement? Anderson signals A BRIEFING OFFICER who hits the lights a an overhead projector which SMASH CUTS TO:
The bridge of the U.S.S. John Pierce, a Gearing class destroyer.  A RADIO OPERATOR addresses a mike in Russian.

Russian-speakers have been transferred to all of our ships.  Once the quarantine takes effect in the morning, our ships will attempt to make radio contact with the approaching vessels.  They will be ordered to reduce speed and prepare for inspection.
MARINES in flak jackets grab M-16s off a rack, race by.
A ship's boat full of Marines lowers away, hits the water engine spraying as it launches forward - in dress rehears
An inspection party will then board and search the ship.  If weapons are found, the ship will be ordered to leave the quarantine area or be towed into port upon refusal.
All eyes are on Admiral Anderson's overhead projections.  Bobby, restless, gets up, begins pacing.
What happens if the ship doesn't stop for inspection or want to be towed?
A warning shot will be fired across its bow. Bobby stops, stares directly at the Admiral.
And what happens if the ship ignores the warning shot?
Then we fire at its rudder, disable it, and carry out the inspection. Kenny looks at the President who remains unmoved, unreada
There will be no shooting without my explicit orders.  Is that understood?
Yes, sir. The President glances at McNamara.
Well, Admiral, it looks like it's up to the Navy.
The Navy won't let you down, sir.
General, have we developed any more information on the missiles?
They are continuing to proceed with the development.  We're commencing low-level photography runs this morning.
The pictures will be used to firm up our estimates of the missiles' readiness and develop target packages for strikes should you order them.

Our guy running this show is the best.  Commander Bill Ecker of the Navy's VFP 62, the Fightin' Photo.  Something of a character, but the highest efficiency ratings we've ever had. He pushes Ecker's personnel file across the table, and as President opens it, on ECKER'S PHOTO, we SMASH CUT TO:

The man himself, COMMANDER BILL ECKER, 30s, playing cards smoking cigars with his wingman, LIEUTENANT BRUCE WILHEMY the PILOTS of VFP-62, the 'Fightin' Photo.'  They lounge, tinker with equipment.  Their ready room is filled with p ups, movie posters, and all things photographic.
75 millimeter, I'm listening.  On the big screen there's nothing like it. The other pilots heckle him, but are muted by Taylor.
To protect our pilots, we're prepared to retaliate against any SAM site or anti aircraft battery that opens fire.
Watch out, Hollywood.  There's a new epic director in town!
EXCOM listens in sober silence.
We have a flight of Thunderchiefs able to respond within minutes of an attack on our planes. Kenny catches the President's eye.  Kenny glances at the door.  Step outside, I need to talk to you.
The President and Kenny stand in front of the President's desk.  All the doors are shut.  Weak sunlight filters int the hushed room as if to a confessional.
I don't like what's happening.
In the morning I'm taking charge of the blockade from the situation room.  McNamara'll set up shop in the flag plot at the Pentagon, keep an eye on things there.
All right.  'Cause you get armed boarders climbing into Soviet ships, shots being fired across bows...
I know, I know...
What about these low-level flights?  They're starting in what?  An hour?  Do you realize what you're letting yourself in for?
We need those flights.  We have to know when those missiles become operational, because when they do, we need to destroy them.

Fair enough.  But Castro's on alert and we're flying attack planes over their sites, on the deck.  There's no way for them to know they're carrying cameras, not bombs.  They're going to be shot at, plain and simple. Kenny's right, and the President looks away in frustratio

I'm your political advisor, and I'm giving you political analysis here.  This is a setup.  The Chiefs want to go in.  It's the only way they can redeem themselves for the Bay of Pigs.  They have to go in, and they have to do it right.  It's that simple.
I'm gonna protect those pilots. Thep President stares intently at Kenny.  Kenny glances a the door, his voice hushed.  He hesitates.

They're boxing us in with these rules of engagement.  If you agree to 'em, and one of our planes gets knocked down or one of the ships won't stop for inspection, the Chiefs will have us by the balls and will force us to start shooting.  They want a war, and they're arranging things to get one.  If you don't want one, we have to do something about it. The President understands.  He shakes his head, paces awa
How does a man get to a place where he can say, 'throw those lives away,' so easily?

Maybe it's harder for them to say it than they let on.  At the very least, they believe it's in our best interest.  And at the end of the day, they may end up being right. The President turns away, considers.  Then turns back.

Triple check everything the Chiefs say to us with the guys who actually have to do it.  No one's to know about this but Bobby.  I need redundant control over what happens out there.  And if things aren't as advertised, you're going to make sure they come out the way I want them to come out, starting with this low level flight thing. Jesus Christ...Kenny is daunted.  For a beat he just star
That's going to be tough.  You know how these guys are about their chains of command...
Any problems, you remind them those chains of commands end at one place.  Me.
Kenny and the President head for the Cabinet Room.  Rusk comes out before they get there.
Mr. President. The OAS meeting starts in an hour.  I haven't prepared at all.  We can't expect --
-- we need this one, Dean.  The quarantine's legal if we get a mandate, otherwise it's an act of war in the eyes of the world.  Get me that vote.  Make it unanimous.
Mr. President, The Organization of American States hasn't had a unanimous vote since -- The President moves for the Cabinet Room.
-- unanimous, Dean. Kenny slaps the dismayed Rusk on the back, heads off down hall away from the Cabinet Room.

Kenny opens the door to the White House switchboard room. half-dozen OPERATORS work their lines, making connections the old-fashioned switchboard.  Unnoticed, he sizes them their skill.  They're all courteous, pretty, professional The CAMERA PANS down the line... and stops on a middle-ag matron at the end - the sternest, most scary of them all. Her name is MARGARET.
White House Operator.  Yes sir. (beat, harsh, booming)
Speaker McCormack, hold for the Vice President. Her voice is so severe, so smoker-gravelled, it makes the blood run cold.  This is the woman Kenny's looking for.
Ma'am, would you mind helping me out with a few special calls?
Ecker, Wilhemy and their Pilots are in angry debate.
Orson Welles is a hack.  Now you want to talk about a director, you talk about David Lean...
Welles is a G-d.  Lean's the hack.
Bullshit, Bruce, nobody but Lean is making decent movies these days. (to Young Pilot)
Get that fixed yet? Nearby, a YOUNG PILOT tinkers with a $300,000 spy camera.
Uhhh... yup.  Think so. Suddenly, the door opens and a pale DUTY SERGEANT enters.
Sir...telephone, sir.
Ecker enters, marches over to the phone.  All the SOLDIER the room stare at him.  Ecker wiggles his cigar to a corn of his mouth, picks up, styling.
VFP-62, Fightin' Photo, here.  But what we really want to do is direct.
Margaret works her magic.
This is the White House Operator.  Hold for the President.
Ecker blinks, becomes a mild lamb.
Oh shit.
Honey, you don't know what shit is.
Kenny, sitting on his desk, taps his fingers, looks at th phone.  He's kept Ecker on hold long enough - and picks u
Commander, my name is Ken O'Donnell.  Special Assistant to the President.
Ecker exhales.  It's not the President, but Ecker is so shaken up it might as well be.
Yes, sir.
The President has instructed me to pass along an order to you. (beat)
You are not to get shot down. Did he hear right?
Uh... we'll do our best, sir.

I don't think you understand me correctly.  You are not to get shot down under any circumstances.  Whatever happens up there, you were not shot at.  Mechanical failures are fine; crashing into mountains, fine.  But you and your men are not to be shot at, fired at, launched upon.
Ecker sits down in a chair, sobered.
Excuse me, sir, what's going on here?
Kenny stands, drops the hard nose bullshit.

Commander, if you are fired upon, the President will be forced to attack the sites that fire on you.  He doesn't want to have to do that.  It's very important that he doesn't, or things could go very badly out of control.
Ecker lets out a long breath.
I think I understand.  What about my men?  If it comes up hot and heavy, and we don't have anyone to protect us... I'm going to be writing letters to parents.  I hate writing letters to parents.
Kenny nods to himself, feeling.  He's done it himself.
If the President protects you, Commander, he may have to do it with the Bomb.
Ecker doesn't want to be avenged with atomic weapons.  No sane person would.

I've known the man for fifteen years.  The problem is, he will protect you.  So I'm asking: don't make him protect you.  Don't get shot at. Ecker down, deeply affected.  Suddenly, A BELL RINGS.  A TELETYPE goes off.  Ecker knows it's for him.  His orders
Okay, Mr. O'Donnell.  We'll do what we can. END INTERCUT. As Ecker hangs up, the Duty Officer rips off the ORDERS, hands them to Ecker, who takes one look, then gazes out t window at the runway --
A CART speeds down the flight line past the waiting F8U-1 Corsairs.  One by one, the four pilots accompanying Ecker Wilhemy jump off to mount their planes.  The cart still moving.
Get that fuel assayed?

Yeah.  It sucks.  Ain't for high performance babies like ours.  Shoulda brought some from home, but what can you do?  Last-second deployments... Wilhemy jumps off, then they're at Ecker's plane, and he jumps off.  Too late to worry about bad fuel now.  He hoi himself up and into the cockpit of the sleek navy jet.
As the canopy closes, Ecker powers up the engines, talks his flight over the Guard channel.
Okay, time to play Spin the Bottle with our bearded buddy.  Nobody gets out ahead.  Remember, just sitting here we're only ten minutes from target.

The Crusaders swing around in pairs at one end of the run and then the first two throttle-up, flaps down, and drop their brakes.  The machines LUNGE forward like duelling d racers.  The FILL THE SCREEN, blow past.

The six Crusaders, in pairs, streak over the buildings an streets of Key West.  And in a heartbeat, cross the beach are out to sea. And already on the horizon, the low clouds and dark line land.  Cuba.  Ninety miles away.

The ocean shrieks past so close you can see the white foa Ecker checks the altimeter: 150 FEET. A small fishing boat looms ahead, its net booms reaching like tree limbs.  The Crusader rockets over it. Ecker checks his instruments.  OUT THE WINDOW, the other Crusaders thunder over the water, past sailboats, cabin cruisers, the small-craft traffic outside Key West.  The speed sucks the breath away.
Go to military throttle on my mark.  Three...two...one... mark. His airspeed indicator spins up to 400 knots.  And then h radio suddenly crackles:
Flameout flameout!
Shit!  Me too!
Get some altitude! Two of the Crusaders pull up, away from the water.
Oh, God damn.  Got it restarted.
Yeah.  Yeah.  Me too.  Goddamn fuel.
Sir, I don't think she's gonna hold up for the run.
Affirmative.  You two get out of here.

The two planes with bad fuel pull wingovers to their left head for the airfield in the distance.  The four remainin planes streak over the ocean.  There are no more small cr this far out in the strait.
Cuba, green and hazy, looms in the window.  Ecker throws series of switches.

Start your camera checks. A mechanical WHINE accompanies the switch-throwing.  Ecke pulls the trigger on his joystick and a THUMP THUMP THUMP hammers away.  There are green lights across his boards. One of the other pilots cuts in on the radio:
Failure.  All cameras.  Sonofabitch.  Film must not have fed.
Jesus!  Shit!  Oh shit!  I just shot it all, boss.  Activator jammed open, its exposing everything now.
That's alright, Lenny, it happens to most men at some time -- Ecker grimaces, but his voice stays cool.
-- Scrub, you two.  Get out of here.  Still with me, Bruce?
That's affirm. The two Crusaders who've failed their camera checks break off.  And now Cuba's hills, the Havana sky line are right front of them.
The last two Crusaders streak over the surf, a white wake spray in their jetwash, and cross the beach with a boom.

The planes dip and rise with the green tropical contours, taking us on a sickening roller-coaster ride over Cuban countryside at treetop level. Palm forest, roads, can fields, more palm forest race by. And then, ahead, a large clearing.
Warm 'em up.  We're here.

Cuban ANTI-AIRCRAFT GUNNERS shout as they traverse their guns in their sandbagged emplacement.  The low rippling thunder of the incoming jets becomes an earsplitting ROAR and the Crusaders blast out over the clearing.  The anti aircraft guns open up.
Wilhemy jinks left to avoid a streaking of TRACER FIRE.
Holy shit!

Tracers and flack pepper the air in front of Ecker's Crusader.  METAL PINGS, TINKS, RATTLES off the fuselage.  Anti-aircraft and small arms fire comes up from all over, hitting the planes multiple times.  He surveys the shapes the target zone dead ahead.
Lights. And sees the long, canvas-covered objects on the ground. missiles.  They draw closer.
Camera. A steel fragment CRACKS his window, obscuring our view.
Action. And he thumbs the CAMERA SWITCH.  All twelve B-system cam begin banging away like cannons.

TRACERS lace the air between the two planes as they blast over the missile site.  Over trailers.  Over tents.  Over trucks.  Over trenches.  Over bulldozers. And then they're out over forest again.  It's all over in seconds.  The triple-A stops.  In unison, the two planes right, heading for the distant blue, blue sea.
Kenny paces by the phone.  It rings.  He picks up, listen reacts.  Relief.  And we know the planes have made it bac
Ecker jumps down from the cockpit ladder and turns an eye his battered, pock-marked plane.  Wilhemy and the GROUND CHIEF come running up, the Chief letting out a whistle.
Lookit what daddy done brung home.
You shoulda seen it, Chief, they --
-- damn sparrows.  Must've been migrating.  Guess I hit a couple hundred. (to Wilhemy, stern)
How many did you hit, Bruce? Wilhemy stands there, looking at Ecker, not sure what to of him.  The Crew Chief just starts laughing as more impressed GROUND CREW come up.
A few.  I guess.
Was them 20 or 40 million sparrows? Ecker, sweat-plastered and foul, steps into the Chief's f

Those are bird strikes.  Sparrows to be precise.  Got a problem with that? The Chief stands there, glances at the plane one more tim and shakes his head, 'No.'  Ecker takes the Chief's maintenance clipboard from him, writes in big bold marker BIRD STRIKES.  He thrusts it back into the Chief's hands walks off; the astonished Wilhemy remains behind.
In Kenny's credenza, a small black and white T.V. plays.  WALTER CRONKITE narrates on the television as a train lad with TANKS on flatbeds pulls out of a station.

Massive military preparations are underway throughout the southeast in what Pentagon officials are confirming is the largest mobilization since Korea.  The railways have been nationalized to assist in the deployment, here transporting elements of the U.S. 1st Armored Division from Ft. Hood, Texas. A PHONE RINGS.  Kenny turns from the T.V., turns down Wal Cronkite, as he answers.
Yeah?
George Ball stands at the back of a crowded room filled w applauding OAS DELEGATES.  It's for Rusk, at a podium up front.
Kenny.  The vote just came down.
Kenny opens his door, lets Rusk in.  The President, Bobby half of EXCOM look up.  Rusk stands there somber.
Unanimous.  One abstenation. And then he breaks into a huge grin.  Everyone cheers him
About time something went our way. An Assistant enters behind Kenny.  Kenny senses him, turn the others move to shake hands with Rusk.
Telephone, Mr. O'Donnell.
Kenny, grinning, ducks back into his office, closes the d after the Assistant leaves.  He picks up the phone.
Hello?
Ecker stands at a phone, stares out a window at a replace plane being fueled.  A Crusader, not his shot-up one.
Mr. O'Donnell, I've been ordered to deliver the film to the Pentagon personally.  What's going on?
Kenny thinks fast.  Oh shit.
The Chiefs must want to talk to you. (beat)
Listen to me, Commander, they'll want to know if you were fired on.  Were you?
You could say that, sir.
Commander.  Do not, under any circumstances, tell the Chiefs.

SUPER: E-RING.  Then SUPER: THE PENTAGON Ecker, still in his sweat-drenched flight suit approaches security checkpoint.  GUARDS secure his sidearm and user through a doorway.  A sign over it reads JCS.
The door swings open into the Joint Chiefs' SOUND-PROOFED briefing room known as THE TANK.  LeMay, Taylor and Ander sit there around the table.  Ecker salutes.
Commander William B. Ecker reporting as ordered! LeMay rises, prowls over to Ecker.
Son , I want to know just one thing.  Those bastards shoot so much as a BB gun at you? A long beat.  Sweat runs off Ecker's head.  He can smell LeMay's breath.
Sir, it was a milk run, sir.
Kenny joins the President and General Taylor in the hallw as they head for the Oval Office.
It appears our low-level flights are getting back okay.  Some unconfirmed reports of small-arms fire from some of the missions, but that's it. Slightly behind them, Kenny looks sidelong at Taylor.
Guess we can't blame Khruschev for a few patriotic farmers.  And the ships?
Still heading for Cuba.
All right.  Then I guess it's time.

FLASHBULBS go off all around the room as the President wa in, goes over to his desk.  Reporters observe silently, T cameras track him; Kenny, Bobby and Sorensen watch as the President sits, takes a pen form his pocket.

In accordance with this afternoon's vote at the OAS, the quarantine shall hereby be effective as of ten o'clock tomorrow morning. Kenny observes in silence as the President SIGNS the Proclamation of Interdiction.

The Oval Office has emptied out.  Only Kenny, Bobby, Sore and the President remain.  The President looks out the window, Sorensen sits in a chair in front of the desk.  B and Kenny sit on the edge of the desk.
Last summer I read a book.  The Guns of August.  I wish every man on that blockade line had read that book. The President moves over to the GLOBE by his desk, spins stopping in on Europe.

World War One.  Thirteen million killed all because the militaries of both alliances were so highly attuned to each other's movements and dispositions, afraid of letting the other guy have a theoretical advantage.  And your man in the field, his family at home, couldn't even tell you the reasons why their lives were being sacrificed. (beat)
Why couldn't they stop it? Can we?  The President's fingers turn the globe.  It stop North America.  Kenny and Bobby listen.

And here we are, fifty years later.  One of their ships resists the inspection.  We shoot out its rudder and board.  They shoot down our planes in response.  We bomb their anti-aircraft sites in response to that.  They attack Berlin.  We invade Cuba.  They fire their missiles.  We fire ours. The President sets the globe gently spinning and walks aw
Kenny rubs his eyes, listens to his phone and the WOMAN'S VOICE at the other end.  It's his wife.
When are you going to be home?
I don't know, Helen.  I want you to keep the kids close tomorrow.  Leave the T.V. on, sleep with it on in the bedroom until I tell you you can turn it off.
What's happened?
Nothing.  Nothing you don't know about.  Tomorrow's the big day.  Just have the car ready to go if I call or if the Civil Defense Warning comes on.
What happens to you?  I'm not leaving without you.
I'll be evacuated with the President. A long silence on the other end of the line.
Great.  So while you're under a rock somewhere with the President, what am I supposed to do with your five children? And to that, there is no answer.  A beat, and it's all Ke can promise:
I'll find you.  But we're not going to let it come to that.  I promise.
Kenny hands Bobby and Bundy cups of coffee.  The three me nurse them in the silence of the abandoned cafeteria.
Helen just asked me what sort of arrangements we have for the families.
I just checked myself. (beat)

They're being issued identity cards.  Call comes, and evacuation officers meet them at pre-arranged departure areas.  They go by helicopter to Mount Weather.  We meet them there. Bobby looks at his coffee, then up at Kenny.  He gently shakes his head.  It's all a sham.
Course that's for morale.  The missiles only take five minutes to get here.
Kenny bolts upright from his couch.  He rubs his face, si on the edge in the dark for a beat.  He's not going back sleep.  He grabs his trousers.
Kenny makes his way through the dim, deserted halls.  Somewhere in the distance a phone rings.  He reaches a do

Kenny, bundled in an overcoat, steps outside the North Entrance.  The cool air invigorates him.  He eyes the fen Pennsylvania Avenue beyond it, seeming to isolate this wo from the living city beyond.  He starts for the main gate
A WHITE HOUSE POLICE OFFICER jumps up as Kenny approaches
Would you like me to call a car, Mr. O'Donnell. Kenny checks his watch.
How long will it take to get someone up?
Fifteen minutes, maybe.  To your house, sir? Kenny considers, shakes his head.  He wants to go home, but...
No.  No, I'll let her sleep.  Let 'em sleep. Kenny says it with a certain finality.  The Police Office nods, and Kenny wanders out through the gates, shoulderin the weight of the world.

Kenny makes his way down a sidewalk not far from the Whit House.  A 24-hour drug store's doors are open.  He pauses Inside, a knot of PEOPLE - late-night deliverymen, a cop, store employees - talk in undertones at the counter.  Beh it, a T.V. is signing off with the national anthem.  Sobe voices, sober looks.  Kenny moves on.

A cluster of COLLEGE STUDENTS talk at a news stand.  They waiting for the NEWSIE to cut the bands of the next day's Washington Post, the bundles just being thrown to the sidewalk from the delivery truck.  Kenny approaches. In their thing beards, counter-culture clothes, the kids so young, Kenny so old.  Kenny buys a newspaper, its dire headlines, every story about the crisis.

Kenny, newspaper under his arm, continues down the street Up ahead, the lights are on in a Catholic Church.  Lines CHURCHGOERS are at the door.  Kenny stops, surprised at t sight this late.  And then he sees the hand-painted banne CONFESSIONS 24 HOURS.  PRAY FOR PEACE. Kenny is moved.  He glances over his shoulder, and then.. joins the line himself.
Kenny's WATCH reads one minute til ten o'clock.  PULL BAC

Kenny, standing just inside the open doors to the White H Situation Room, a state-of-the-art conference room.  A lo central table surrounded by leather chairs with phones an screens built in.  T.V. monitors hang from the ceilings i the corners.  There are no windows, just oppressive bunke like walls.  It's far underground. Across the room the President paces, phone in hand.  Half EXCOM is in their seats.  The other half, along with a st stream of DUTY OFFICERS, are coming and going.  Kenny ste aside for a Duty Officer, listens to the President.
Okay, Bob, I'm putting you on intercom. Suddenly, McNamara's VOICE fills the room.
Hey, guys, can you hear me?
McNamara stands, phone in hand.
I have one minute til ten here --

head_text.subj: THE CAMERA TRACKS AROUND HIM, REVEALING

text: A large, elaborate war room, like Mission Control.  Big screens, plexiglass tracking boards, tiered banks of communications equipment.  A massive LIGHT TABLE on the f at the center of the room projects a map of the Caribbean Atlantic.  Arcing across it is a RED LINE: the blockade. The map is covered with cryptic military notations; WATCH OFFICERS on a platform which swings out over it update th latest ship positions. McNamara's in a booth overlooking the room.  It's open to next tier below where Admiral Anderson is giving orders.
-- and no sign of them stopping.

Kenny and Bobby move to the President's end of the table, down across from each other in mirror-image fashion.  EXC looks to the President.  The second hand of the clock on wall wheels past 12.  A hush falls over the room.
Bob, the quarantine is now in effect.
McNamara is mute for a beat.  He turns to view the big ro

Then it looks like our first customers are the Gagarin and Kimovsk. He nods to Admiral Anderson, who calls an order down to a Watch Officer on the floor, and on screens all around the room, a sector of the map MAGNIFIES the unfolding encount

-- between the destroyer, U.S.S. Pierce and the SOVIET FREIGHTERS Gagarin and Kimovsk.  The Pierce's bridge wing are crammed with helmeted OFFICERS and LOOKOUTS.  They pe through binoculars at the distant ships, plowing ahead, straight for them.  The CAPTAIN lowers his binoculars, determined.
Helm, shape heading for intercept, zero one zero.  All ahead full --
-- new contact!  New contact! Everyone whirls to the bridge.  The Captain steps forward
The Captain ducks into the CIC.  The CHIEF SONARAN report
Submerged contact, designation Sierra one at 6000 yards bearing 030.
A submarine...
The President reacts.  Kenny and Bobby react.
It's protecting the freighters. Consternation.  The President picks up the phone.
Bob, is there any way we can avoid stopping a submarine first?

I'm afraid not, Mr. President.  The sub has positioned itself between the Pierce and the Soviet ships.  Admiral Anderson insists it's too much of a risk to proceed with stopping the freighters.  The Pierce would be a sitting duck for the sub. All around the room frustration.  Bobby shakes his head.  Kenny sinks back in his chair.  The President hesitates.
Put me through to the Pierce.

Admiral Anderson nods to a COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER.  The m makes the connection on a switchboard. McNamara casts an eye to the map.  The two red MARKERS labeled Gagarin and Kimovsk are joined by a third: the SU They are ALMOST TOUCHING the blockade line.  On the other side, the single blue marker for the Pierce.
