So we reject the second letter. And Kenny looks at Bobby.  The world stops.
No.  We don't reject it... It hits Bobby like a lightning bolt.
... We accept the first letter and pretend the second doesn't exist. The President, Rusk and Sorensen stare at him, mute.
HOLD ON the exact same mute reaction from the entire assembled EXCOM.  Finally McCone breaks the spell.
It won't work -- Bobby, Kenny and Sorensen start to object, but McCone rai his voice over theirs.

-- because it's wishful thinking!  It's the same wishful thinking that blinded us all these months while the Soviets were sneaking those missiles in under our noses! McNamara shakes his head, intrigued but skeptical.
Ignore the second letter, agree to the conditions of the first...
There's no reason to believe the Soviets will let it go.
Max is right.  Why will they accept it?
It can work.  If, IF they believe we'll hit them. Kenny, Bobby and Sorensen look at McNamara, grateful.
We've only got time for one more round of diplomacy.  The first airstrikes start in less than 36 hours.
But we have to make them agree to it.  So how do we do that? The President leans forward.  Sensing he's about to speak all eyes turn to him.

We give them something.  We tell them we'll remove the missiles from Turkey say, six months from now so that there appears to be no linkage.  We also tell them if they go public about it, we deny it and the deal is off.
And we do it under the table so we can disavow any knowledge of it.
It's transparent.  The press'll be all over it.
Six months from now, I'm not going to care.  Are you?  We'll deal with it.
At least it will expose whether Khruschev has been overthrown.  We'll know what we're dealing with.

And if this is a move to appease the hard line, then it may just be the bone he needs to regain control of his own house. Most EXCOM is nodding, agreeing.  McCone shakes his head disgust.  Taylor sits in silence.
Whoever carries the message has to hit the nail on the head.  Come across as too soft, they'll push us.  Too hard, they'll be cornered and even more dangerous.

They could pre-empt. It's a terrible responsibility to bear.  The room is sile At last Bobby looks up from his folded hands to his broth The President stares back.  There is nobody else who can this.  Only Bobby. His brother.
Bobby.  You know Dobrynin best. Bobby nods, taking up the gauntlet.
Ted, you get working on the draft. Sorensen and Bobby rise as one, head for the doors.
And make sure he knows we have to have an answer tomorrow. (beat, final)
Because on Monday we begin military action against Cuba. Bobby and Kenny exchange a look.

A LONG SHOT: Bobby emerges from the West Wing in his overcoat, briefcase in hand.  He pauses, tiny, alone.  Th West Wing - and all its imposing spotlit power behind him reduced to this insignificant man on his eleventh-hour mission. And then, out of the shadows, in the f.g., steps Kenny in own coat, his breath frosting in the late-night air.  Bob sees him, and knows he is not so alone anymore.
They meet in front of the limo.  Bobby stops, shuffles hi things, awkward.
What do you want?  A good-bye kiss? Kenny opens the driver's side door.  The Secret Service L DRIVER peers out.
Hey, Kenny.
Hey, Joe.  Listen, I'll take care of him.  Go ahead in, grab some coffee.  We'll be back pretty quick.
You sure? Kenny's nod and look -- there's no arguing.  The Limo Dri hops out, and Kenny gets in.  Bobby stands there outside a beat.  He tries to hide how touched he is, but can't completely.
What's the matter with you?  Forget how to open a car door?
Bobby recovers, opens his own door, gets in the front sea next to Kenny.
Jesus, you rich people. Kenny starts up the engine.  Bobby smiles a twisted smile As the car pulls away, the two men sit in silence, neithe willing to admit how glad the other is there.
The limo wheels out into the street, carrying the two fri into the darkness.

Bobby stares out the window at the passing city, the ligh the lives behind those windows.  As the car drives on and the tension returns.  Bobby feels the weight of all those lives.  On him.  A long beat.  He gazes at Kenny, the onl man he could ever admit this to:
I don't know if I can do this. Kenny glances over at him.  Bobby stares back.
There's nobody else I'd rather have going in there. Bobby looks at him.
Nobody else I'd trust Helen and the kids' lives to. Kenny means it.  He looks away.  Bobby shifts, awkward.
Take a left. Kenny looks him.  This isn't the way to the Justice Department.  But he complies.
We gave so much to get here.  I don't know.  Sometimes I think what the hell did we do it for?
Because we knew we could do a better job than everyone else. And Bobby, in the silence and closeness of the car, turns Kenny - anguished, knowing his life is at its climax.
You know... I hate being called the brilliant one.  The ruthless one.  They guy who does the dirty work.  The one everybody's afraid of.   Kenny looks to him, moved, not knowing what to say.
I hate it.  I'm not smart, you know.  And I'm not so ruthless. He looks to Kenny, searching his face, then away, embarrassed.
You're right about the smart part, but ruthless, well... That breaks the tension as they arrive at the scene:

Appears the grim, square lines of the SOVIET EMBASSY.  Po cars line the streets outside it.  All the windows are da A cordon of KGB GUARDS in plainclothes stand by the gated entrance.  On the opposite side of the street lounge two dozen WASHINGTON D.C. POLICE.
Kenny gives Bobby a look.  Bobby rolls down his window.
Slow down.  Smell that?
Smoke.
Just wanted to see for myself. (beat)
They're burning their documents. The final duty of an embassy before war...
They think we're going to war.  G-d help us, Ken.

THE CAMERA lifts away from the limo, turning toward the Embassy, past the Guards, past the brass plate which read EMBASSY OF THE UNITED SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS, up and to the roof where black, reeking SMOKE billows from all o the Embassy's several chimneys. The CAMERA races into it.  It engulfs us all.
Kenny squeals the limo up to the curb in front of the Jus Department.  The doors fly open, and Kenny and Bobby jump out, head up the steps to the building.
Bobby's STAFFERS greet them as they stride down the hall, Staffer #1 taking Bobby's coat.
Sir, Ambassador Dobrynin is already here.  We have him waiting in your office. They reach the double oak doors to Bobby's suite and stop Bobby faces Kenny.

I'll whistle up some luck for you. And before Kenny's eyes, all of Bobby's doubt vanishes. its place, a severe confidence.  A grandeur Kenny has nev seen. It makes Kenny pause.  He beholds his best friend become man of the ages.  And then Bobby SMOOTHLY opens the door.

And a DOOR SHUTS OC like a threshold of history.  HOLD ON Bobby's waiting room.  Silent.  Cavernous.  Dim.  Plush carpet.  Heavy drapes framing dark windows.  And abandone secretary's desk.  A row of sofas and chairs on either si of the room.  Two doorways, one at either end of the room A WOMAN sits in one of the chairs for visitors.  Dressed gray.  Prim.  But beautiful.  A secretary of some sort. One of the double doors to the hall swings silently open. Kenny glides in.  He sees the other door shut at the far of the room.  Kenny crashes in one of the chairs to wait. HOLD ON THE SCENE, motionless, silent. Kenny WHISTLES two notes.  Stops.  And then he begins to WHISTLE the Irish tune, O'Donnell Aboo.  He gets a bar in it -- and there's a polite, soft COUGH. Kenny stops.  Then notices the Woman in gray across the r He didn't see her.  It's dim over there.  She looks at hi expressionless. The CAMERA FINDS: a pin on her lapel.  A RED HAMMER AND SICKLE. Kenny reacts.  Dobrynin's assistant?  His opposite number friend?  Or more than a friend? Here is the face of the enemy.  Not a smile between them. Kenny resumes his ease.  And begins to WHISTLE again. The haunting Irish song echoes in the vaulted ceiling, filling the dim room.  Strange, sad, beautiful.  The woma listens.  And her face begins to soften.   Kenny stares at the dark, lonely windows, his SONG strivi to fill the empty room. Kenny sinks deeper in the chair, his tune all-consuming.. and the Woman's voice breaks in.  Kenny stops, looks over Her voice is tremulous and beautiful.  Just a snatch of s song in Russian.  She stops, awkward. Kenny stares.  The Woman stares back.  No smiles.  But in their eyes, they each see the other's fear, the other's beauty, the other's humanity. So this is the enemy.
Who are you? Kenny glances to the door.  He considers for a long momen
The friend. Kenny breaks the gaze.  He begins to whistle again.  The CAMERA drifts away, finding the far DOOR to the inner off Kenny's tune stronger, carrying with it hope...

... to the other side of that DOOR.  Dobrynin sits in a c opposite Bobby behind his desk.  The room is equally dim. And far more tense. Silence.  And then the FAINTEST STRAIN of O'Donnell Aboo. Dobrynin glances briefly over his shoulder at the door. But Bobby, unseen by Dobrynin, can't help the flicker of private smile.  It's Kenny's presence, and Bobby is the stronger for it.  And then the tune is gone. Bobby leans forward, cool, controlled, masterful.
Ambassador Dobrynin, we are aware that at this moment your missiles in Cuba are at the brink of operational readiness...

Floodlights illuminate MISSILES, vertical on their erecto support VEHICLES, clustered across the man-made clearing. Mask-wearing Technicians wave a FUEL TRUCK back to the nearest missile.  Clouds of toxic VAPOR rise from the oth They've already been fueled.
They are a vital threat to my country.  If launched, they would kill 80 million Americans.
Dobrynin listens impassively, as is his professional duty
My brother, my friends, my countrymen and I cannot and will not permit those missiles to become operational. (beat)
I promise you that. Dobrynin looks out the window.  And then, pained, looks b at Bobby.
Then I fear our two nations will go to war.  And I fear where war will lead us. Bobby acknowledges him with a nod.
If the missiles do not become operational, if you remove the missiles, then there will be no war. (beat)

At this moment, the President is accepting the terms of Secretary Khruschev's letter of Friday night.  If the Soviet Union halts construction immediately, removes the missiles, and submits to U.N. inspection, the United States will pledge to never invade Cuba or aid others in that enterprise. Dobrynin stares at Bobby.  Stares hard.
If your Jupiter missiles in Turkey were removed also, such an accommodation could be reached. The two men move their argument forward with the delibera and formality of chess masters.
(tired sounding)
The United States cannot agree to such terms under threat.  Any belief to the contrary -- (beat)
-- was in error. Dobrynin reels internally.  The only sign on his face is slight tremor.  Bobby looks up, registers the calculated effect.  And to Dobrynin's horror, the Russian believes:
You want war... But not so fast.  Bobby folds his hands.  And he smoothly goes from hard-ass brinksman to sensitive deal-maker.
However, while there can be no quid pro quo on this issue, the United States can offer a private assurance. Dobrynin holds his breath.
Our Jupiter missiles in Turkey are obsolete, and have been scheduled for withdrawal for some time.  This withdrawal should be completed within, say, six months. Dobrynin lets out his breath.

Of course, any public disclosure of this assurance would negate the deal and produce the most stringent denials from our government. Dobrynin grasps the move immediately, understanding the ramifications.  Still he hesitates a moment.
This private assurance represents the word of the Highest Authority?
Yes.
And it can be relayed beyond Comrade Khruschev's ears to the top circles of my government

Of course.  Our pledge can be relayed to any government official Secretary Khruschev sees fit to satisfy. Meaning this is the bone he can show the hard line.  Dobr struggles internally, knowing what Bobby has done, wantin hug him.  It comes across as agitation.
With the caveat that it is not made public in any way, shape or form. (beat)
And we must have an answer tomorrow at the latest.  I cannot stress this point enough.
Tomorrow...
Tomorrow... Dobrynin rises from his chair.  Bobby rises with him.
Then you must excuse me and permit me to relay the substance of our discussion to my superiors. Dobrynin heads for the door.  Half way there he turns bac Bobby, deeply moved.  Deeply grateful.
We have heard stories that some among your military men wish for war. (beat)

You are a good man.  Your brother is a good man.  I assure you there are other good men.  Let us hope the will of good men is enough to counter the terrible strength of this thing which has been put in motion.

Kenny enters the Oval Office through his side door.  The office is dark, only the desk lamp on.  Kenny's gaze move over the trappings of power: the carpet with the Presiden Seal, the rocking chair by the fireplace, the desk. And on the desk, tucked almost out of sight, sits a small humble wooden plaque.  It's turned to face the occupant o the chair behind the desk.  Kenny reaches out, turns it around.  It is the Breton's Fisherman's Prayer. It reads: OH LORD, THY SEA IS GREAT, MY BOAT SO SMALL.
We're out here. Kenny holds on the plaque a beat, and looks up at the ope French door to the Rose Garden.  The curtains swirl aroun him in the wind as he goes through the door and out --

-- onto the portico.  Standing there in the dark, by the white neoclassical pillars of the cloister, are Bobby and President.  They're holding drinks.  Kenny joins them. The President gestures out across the South Lawn to the gleaming Washington Monument.
We were just debating who had it worse, us or George Washington and his guys.
He didn't have to worry about nuclear weapons.
Yeah, but the country didn't even exist as a country yet.  It was a mess, and he didn't have a leg to stand on.
All he had was his character. The President and Bobby nod at the justice of that remark
How does a guy get a rep like that?
Doesn't matter to me.  If I went down in history like Adams, I'd die happy.  All they say about him today is --

-- he kept the peace. Kenny looks at the President.  The President feels it, an gazes back to him. The three of them stare out at the glittering city.  The grandness of the world lies before them, and they are deciding its fate, and are humbled by the awfulness of it The silence is beyond power. And for a long moment, they know not to disturb it.  Ther nothing left to say.  The President, at last, finishes hi drink.
You know, we never did control it.  Not really.  Not like we think. He looks at Kenny.  Kenny nods.  He knows that now too.
But we did our best.  Now it's up to them.

Kenny's limo pulls away, leaving Kenny, coat in hand, at bottom of his driveway.  He watches it go, silently urgin to return for him with some call from the President telli him he's desperately needed.  But it doesn't. He turns to his house.  The lights are all out. He notices he's CLUTCHING the handle of his briefcase.  H knuckles are white.  With conscious effort, he unfolds hi hand, letting the briefcase drop on the driveway. He stands alone, stripped of his friends, his family, his job... and in that moment, mute, impotent in the shadow o Armageddon, Kenny is our Everyman of the Nuclear Age.
Helen stands in the kitchen, a ghostly white figure in he robe, the windows open and curtain flapping as she breath the air.  Kenny enters.  He stands in the doorway.
I saw you out there.  You want him to call you back, need you.
No.  I'm glad I'm home. And she knows the worst.
How long do we have? Kenny's voice breaks.
If the sun rises in the morning, it is only because of men of goodwill. (beat)

And that's all there is between us and the Devil. They take each other in their arms, the wisdom of the ato age so simple, so tenuous, every human life hanging by su thread... yet a thread so powerful.  The CAMERA RISES FRO THEM, finding the OPEN WINDOW and the DARKNESS.
The RED DOME OF NUCLEAR FIRE rising over Washington.  It roils the air in its expanding, blood-red glory. It is the sun.  The dawn in the East. PULL BACK THROUGH THE OPEN WINDOW.

into Kenny and Helen's bedroom.  And silence.  Kenny and Helen lie together on the bed.  The light burns into Kenn half-shut eye.  Kenny is only dimly conscious of the ligh meaning.  Until the PHONE SHRILLS downstairs. Kenny is instantly up, launched out of the room.
Kenny snatches the RED PHONE from its hook.
Yeah?
Kenny.  It's over.

THE CHURCH BELLS TOLL in raucous celebration.  Kenny, Hel and the five O'DONNELL KIDS join the throng packing throu the doors to the church.  They're all smiling except Kenn who searches fro faces in the CROWD. And then he spots Bobby with his FAMILY.  Bobby grins at That makes Kenny grin back.
This is Radio Moscow.  Moscow calling. But Kenny keeps looking.

The following statement is the text of a letter from General Secretary Khruschev to President Kennedy. Kenny spots him emerging from the Presidential limo, surrounded by Secret Service Agents - John Kennedy.  His FAMILY also is with him.

...I regard with respect and trust the statement you made in your message of 27 October 1962 that there would be no attack, no invasion of Cuba, and not only the part of the United States, but also on the part of the Western Hemisphere, as you said in your same message.  Then the motives which induced us to render assistance of such a kind to Cuba disappear... Kennedy, greeting well-wishers, a brilliant smile on his face, is carried through the crowd toward Kenny and the d of the church.

...it is for this reason that we have instructed our officers - these missiles, as I already informed you are in the hands of Soviet officers to take appropriate measures to discontinue construction, dismantle them, and return them to the Soviet Union.

the base has been half-dismantled over night.  Fuel truck pull away, lumping down the makeshift dirt road.  Across site missiles are lowered, their nose cones being removed A MISSILE on its transporter, Technicians crawling all ov it, COVERING IT with a tarp. A massive Soviet Helicopter's rotors thunder as it lifts cargo crates swaying under it, a CLOUD OF DUST FROM ITS W

head_text.subj: FILLING THE SCREEN, WIPING US TO

text: EXCOM laughing, celebrating, half-drunk already this Sund morning.  The President shushes the group.
Hey!  Hey.  Okay, that's enough. The group quiets down.  The Presidents stares at them, ca firm.  They sober up quickly.  Kenny listens, expectant.
I don't want any gloating.  This is not a victory over the Soviets.  It's a victory with the Soviets. (beat)
I want everyone to remember that.

Kenny rounds a corner.  McNamara, Bundy and McCone are talking, excited, hushed, standing to one side, down the hall.  Kenny eyes them as he draws closer, and then they notice he's approaching.  Bundy nods him over, confidenti
We've been talking.  We can play this big in '64.  It's the foreign policy trophy we've been waiting. Kenny sickens.  He tries to listen, but it all begins to blur.

I think we can ride it all the way home next election.  Bet you're way ahead of us, eh? Bundy slaps Kenny on the back.  Kenny is pale.  Is what they're saying possible?  But Bundy and McCone are too wrapped up in their schemes to notice Kenny's distress.

We've ordered crash reassessment of our major geopolitical hotspots.  We've got a lot of new clout, and we can run the table on the Soviets.  Middle East, Southeast Asia... And Kenny, sad, moved beyond all pity and loathing, reali it is possible.  They haven't gotten it.  He is speechles helplessly shaking his head.  Bundy finally sees somethin isn't right with him.
What's wrong, O'Donnell? Kenny can't speak.  Can't find the words.  But tongue-tie finally manages:
Don't you understand? McNamara and Bundy look at him funny.
Understand what? Kenny just looks at them, eyes filled with sorrow.  They begin to feel uncomfortable.
The sun came up today.
Yeah.
It shouldn't have.  But it did.
We were lucky we were able to keep it under control. Kenny looks away, unable to bear it.
Every day the sun comes up... says something about us.
Says what, Kenny? Kenny looks back at them.
Something... amazing. They just stare at him.  And with secret smiles, superior smiles, they nod.
Sure, Ken.  I understand.  Feels good to win, doesn't it? But they don't understand, and together turn away.
See you later, Kenny. Kenny watches them, heads bowed in discussion, disappear the labyrinth of the West Wing.  Kenny turns his back on them.

The President stands at his mirror, tying a bow tie to a for some Sunday special event.  Kenny gathers up his fold from nearby breakfast table. Kenny meets the President's gaze in the mirror, and the t men know they have been to the same mountaintop.
Kenny... A beat.  Kenny stands straight, ready for action, ready f some necessary thing.  Ready to go back into the game.
...never mind.  See you around, Kenny. Kenny starts to leave, but at the door, turns back.
You know... The President looks at him in the mirror.

...this was what we're here for. The President smiles an ever-so-faint smile.  Kenny turns leaves the room, vanishing, and as we HOLD on the empty doorway, the simple, whistled melody of O'DONNELL ABOO dr from the hallway beyond, becoming our END MUSIC.

Shortly after the crisis President Kennedy ordered a reassessment of U.S.-Soviet relations, ushering a brief t in the Cold War.  During this time, the Washington-Moscow hotline was installed to ensure that in a future crisis, miscommunication would not lead to nuclear war. The President was assassinated on November 22nd, a year a the crisis ended.

Bobby Kennedy ran for president in 1968.  After winning t California primary, he called Kenny from the Ambassador H in Los Angeles and told him, "I finally feel like I'm out from under my brother's shadow." Bobby was assassinated minutes later.

The members of EXCOM continued  to serve with distinction government in various capacities over the next three deca As Lyndon Johnson's Secretary of Defense, Robert McNamara urged containment of the Soviet threat in every theatre o conflict around the world.  He ultimately advised Preside Johnson to increase the U.S. military commitment to one o these minor backwater conflicts: Vietnam.

Kenny O'Donnell witnessed the President's assassination f the car behind.  He went on to head the Peace Platform at 1968 Democratic National  Convention, fighting to end the Vietnam War.  He died in 1977.
